title: How does my ex filing for chapter 7 affect me as it pertains to a second home we own.
question: My ex and I own a second home scheduled to be foreclosed in the coming days. Neither of us can afford it or want to keep it.Short sale was unsuccessful.
question_tags: Bankruptcy,Chapter 7 bankruptcy,Credit,Debt,Bankruptcy and debt,Foreclosure,State, local, and municipal law,Deed in lieu of foreclosure
answers:
If you give the house back, it is done usually through a deed in lieu of foreclosure. However, if the first lender is foreclosing, then the lender will have to foreclose to wipe out the second. If the house is surrendered and you both owe money on it, even if the lender cannot sue you for it because you are not obligated to pay it under state law, there will still be a notation on your credit report that the property was foreclosed upon.

Contact a local attorney for more information specific to your entire financial situation.

In certain circumstances, under California's anti-deficiency statutes, a second mortgage company cannot come after you for a deficiency from foreclosure. You should speak with a bankruptcy attorney in your area to determine whether the lender of the second mortgage is able to recovery the deficiency in your case.

It sounds as if the property will be foreclosed by the bank. Do you know which bank is threatening to sell the property? This is a difficult scenario to answer here and I encourage you to contact an attorney in your area.

With that said, your ex' filing bankruptcy will have no impact on you or your credit history. However the foreclosure of the property will. If the first mortgage is the foreclosing bank and the property is sold at the Trustee's sale, the sale will be on your record. If the second mortgage forecloses, the sale will show against your ex but the first will remain on your credit history as a debt you owe. Whether you remain financially liable for the first if the second forecloses is a topic you should discuss with an attorney.

Good luck.
